. More than just a medium-sized city between
, Jundiaí is renowed by its wineries and  traditional fruit farms open to visitors, as well as by the
, a rainforest-covered mountain range with unique characteristics.
In 1615, the region called by Native Brazilians as "Jundiahi" was settled by

Rafael de Oliveira. Jundiaí was officially recognized as a village in 1655, and dedicated itself to mining on its early decades of existance, followed soon by a period of economical stagnation. This started to change in 1785 with the boom of agriculture, including fruit cultivation, which is still one of the main characteristics of the region today. With the inauguration of the train station in 1867, Jundiaí started receiving a lot of European immigrants (from

. But as the only large city of the state outside the São Paulo metro area to still have a fully operational passenger train station, urban Jundiaí contains important testimonies of the shining days of rail transport in Brazil. Not by coincidence, Jundiaí is likely to be the first city in the state to have a rapid train service, around 2016.
Jundiaí is easily accessible from either São Paulo (50 minutes) or Campinas (40 minutes) by
). From São Paulo, a frequently used alternative is to take
), and change to Rod. Anhanguera shortly before arriving in Jundiaí.
Jundiaí is one of the few places outside the São Paulo metro area where it is possible to arrive by train. The CPTM train of
, that departs from Luz station in

, is ridiculously cheap (same price as a regular CPTM/Metrô ticket) but since it is a stop train, it is a tad slow (takes at least 1:20 hours, plus transfer time at Francisco Morato station). The train can also get overcrowded at peak hours, making it a good option only if you have small luggage and are on a tight budget. The Jundiaí train station is about 1.7 km from the city center, and approximately the same distance to Museu da Companhia Paulista.
Getting to Jundiaí by bus is a far more confortable option than the CPTM train. The intercity bus terminal of Jundiaí is
, located at Av. 9 de Julho, 4000. A local bus or a taxi is necessary to reach the city center from the terminal.

value: (departing from the Tietê terminal) are provided by Viação Cometa

Buses from both São Paulo and Campinas are quite frequent and seldom require reservation.

The city center and its attractions can be easily explored on foot. To explore the countryside and the nature around the city, however, you will need a car or hire one of the tour agencies that operate in the city.

value: content=The imponent construction, although looking centenary, was actually built in 1979 to pay  homage to the ferroviary history of the São Paulo state. It contains an extensive amounts of artifacts from the glorious times of rails during the coffee farming era, plus replicas of trains and interiors of train stations.
name=Catedral da Nossa Senhora do Desterro
address=Praça Governador Pedro de Toledo, s/n – Centro

content=Splendid Neogothic style cathedral that is one of the main postcards of Jundiaí. The exact date of building is unknown, but it was reformed from Baroque to Neogothic style in 1886, and sits in the same place of the original chapel of Jundiaí (from 1651).
alt=Museu Histórico e Cultural de Jundiaí

content=A 1862 mansion that was used by Antônio de Queiróz Telles, a local aristocrat known as the "Jundiaí Baron". Hosts a permanent exposition about the "Jundiaí Baron" and other relevant figures in the history of the city, plus temporary expositions and cultural activities.
address=Praça Mauá - Vila Arens e Vila Progresso

content= Jundiaí train station, inaugurated in 1867 and operating ever since. Alongside its history, it belonged to four companies: São Paulo Railway, E.F. Santos-Jundiaí, RFFSA and CPTM (its current owner).
directions=In front of the Jundiaí station, in the other side of Praça Mauá
content=The collection of colorful, similar houses in front of the Jundiaí stations belonged to workers of São Paulo Railway and is a national heritage site.
content=This state park just south of town has the largest forest preserve in the state, with opportunities for extreme sports.

content=Inaugurated in 1911, it is one of the 6 centenary theatres of the country, being for some time the largest theatre of the state. Closed during the 1960s, it was reformed and reactivated in 1996. Check the municipality cultural agenda for presentations in the theatre
